°ERMAN UNIVERSITY LIFE.
I have been ,asked to write of certain phases
of student life in Germany. To understand
the German student one must know his previous school training. In the German grammar schools a boy who does not do his work
or is unruly is thrashed. in the high school—
called the Gymnasium—he is not thrashed, but
lighter offenses or poor work are punished by
house-arrest; i. e., his parents are informed
that for a given period he must remain in his
room outside of school hours, and do extra
tasks; continued insufficient scholarship entails
repeating the, work of the year, thus bringing
him to the university a year later than his
classmates; for graver offenses or incapacity
he is expelled.
This system has the approval of parents and
of the nation; its rigid discipline is in glaring
contrast with the democratic spirit of the American training school and college. Suffice it to
say that it suits Germany, and that it has certain obvious advantages. For nine years, and
those the years in which memory is most plastic, the boy, who has had good previous training in the grammar school, is compelled in the
Gymnasium to study hard, and learn thoroughly. The average result is a broad, thorough, and above all a lasting knowledge of his
own language and literature, of his country
and its resources, of classical and German history, of the classics and mathematics, and some
knowledge of modern languages, science, and
general history.
When the young man leaves the Gymnasium,
his education has reached a point which may
be roughly compared to the end of the junior
year in our colleges. Hence it follows that
German students are older than our college
students, the average age of entering the university being 19-20; that they all have a definite aim—medicine, law, etc.; that the univer-

No. 16

sity is a place for professional studies only;
and hence that'young men intending a business
life do not go to the University.
Yet one must not think that the German
student enters the university with the feelings
of an American graduate student, though his
aims are identical, and his educational status
nearly so. Without transition he comes from
the severe discipline of the school to absolute
freedom in the university; he may attend lectures or stay away for months at a time; he
may rarely enter the university buildings and
yet remain a student. Barring habits of work,
sense of duty, and comradeship, he has but two
incentives to work: First, how many years his
parents are willing to support him at the university; second, that he cannot practice law,
medicine or any other branch of learning in
Germany without passing certain examinations. Government sets a minimum university
residence before examination, varying from
three to five years, according to the subject of
study; the student may prolong this period indefinitely. Students who are poor, or exceptionally studious, usually pass the examinations
after the allotted minimum residence, and as a
rule take only a modest part in the characteristic pleasures of student life; most others stay
from six months to a year—often two years—
longer in residence, with consent of their parents, who wish them to enjoy a year or two
of comparative freedom from professional
study, that they may in part broaden their
knowledge in outside studies, in part share in
student life.
It must not be thought that this period is
commonly spent in loafing. A young man who
has graduated from the best schools in the
world has learned one thing at all events: he
has learned how to.work ; he can apply himself
closely to his studies,while indulging with equal
ardor in fencing matches or drinking bouts

2

T HE N EWS-LETTER.

later in the day. Indeed, that blot on democracy, the lack-lustre type of loafer which
reaches its highest perfection on the porch of
our village stores, vacuous in mind, empty of
purpose, and which in a more refined form occasionally gains entrance to our colleges, loafing through school, loafing through college, is
unknown in German universities; indeed, it is
almost unknown in Germany, thanks to their
system of enforced military service.
The German student, then, usually craves
occupation. What has he in place of our college life ? There is no class spirit" ; no one
thinks of himself as member of "the class of
'99"; it's a go-as-you-please race for graduation. There is scarce any "college spirit"; no
one asks, "Were you a Munich man?" They
ask, "Whom did you study under?" Many
students divide their time between two or three
universities, thus working with different distinguished teachers. Athletics as we understand the term are unknown, nor have they a
substitute in form of any game. Indoor athletics were compulsory at school. Some keep
on in the Turnschule provided by the university; unfortunately, there is a certain association ip the German mind of indoor gymnastics
with ultra-liberal political opinions, dating from
the days of "Turnvater Jahn," and the participation of student Turners in revolutionary
movements, which tends to keep many students
from the Turnschule.
Cycling, swimming,
boating, and mountaineering receive ever increasing interest. The Academische Gesangverein, with its high musical standards, attracts
the musically inclined, many in number. The
concerts of these societies are very enjoyable.
The picturesque side of student life is with
the Corps, the Burschenschaften, and their imitators. These bodies correspond to the American secret societies. The Corps are the lineal
descendant of the Landsmannschaften of the
middle ages, when all Saxons, for example, at
a given university, formed a corporation for
mutual help, often fighting in the streets, sword
in hand, against students from another province. In the general overturn of German
States and institutions under the Napoleonic
domination, the Landsmannschaften dropped

out of existence, but their names were retained
by their successors, the Corps. Now, corps
take members without reference to their home.
Some Corps are exclusive and expensive, some
the reverse. All have the following points in
common: Each Corps consists of Burschen, or
full members, and of Foxes, or probationers;
a Fox is usually made Bursch in eight months
or a year. Each Corps has three officers, or
"charges," which we may call president, vicepresident, treasurer; the vice-president has
charge of the dwelling. Each Corps is independent of all others, subject to general laws
laid down by the "Kosen Senioren-Convent,"
an annual assembly of delegates from all German Corps. Identity of name of Corps in different universities in no way implies affiliation.
Students of each Corps wear distinctive caps
and ribbon across the breast, of three colors
for the Bursch, of two for the Fox. All Corps
students"give satisfaction," to use the student
phrase, i. e., fight duels with the Schlager, a
heavy-hilted, light-bladed sword, on the most
trivial grounds, and lacking such, by simple arrangement of the vice-presidents. The Corps
have regular convivial meetings twice or thrice
weekly, when songs are sung and much—far
too much—beer is drunk. The Corps students
is not a Whitmanesque creature of impulse;
he is bound in things great and small by a
minute traditional etiquette. There are codified laws for dwelling, Pauk-comment; for beer
drinking, Bier-comment. Suppose a student to
pour wine or beer into his glass without murmuring "ohne" (abbreviation of ohne Bier
vergenden u wollen), he has committed a
grave offense. The learned in the law hold
that ohne should be said even if water be
poured, since it is clearly possible that the
pitcher might previously have contained beer,
and thus a drop might so temper and ennoble
the water as to bring it within spiritual relationship to beer, though to the outward eye it be
plain water. The offending student is condemned by the president to a penalty—song or
drink. He may appeal and demand trial; an
impromptu court is held with counsel, and
clever speeches, sometimes in Latin wonderfully burlesqued. The student who demands

THE NEWS-LETTER.
trial must order three glasses of schnaps for
judge and counsel. Tradition demands that
they refuse it as hurtful to the stomach, and
that it be drunk by the waiter! During term
time it is etiquette for the student to ignore
the existence of a member of a rival Corps,
though they may be old friends; with the
moment of close of term, they are again friends.
Hazing is unknown. There is no initiation
analogous to that of American secret societies.
The chief difference between Corps and
BursChenschaft is that the latter avow advanced
democratic political opinions. The Burschenschafts "give satisfaction," and fight among
each other, but chiefly with the Corps. Other
societies wear colored cap and ribbon, but "re:
fuse satisfaction" ; the students belonging to
them are generally a shabby lot; some of these
latter societies are semi-religious, Catholic or
Protestant.
A Fox equipped for a fight is a strange
object; with his body protected by a padded
leather apron, his neck by a broad, wadded silk
band, half covering the chin, his eyes by a sort
of stone-masons' goggles without glasses, his
temples by a light cap with broad visor; he is
to American eyes as comical as one of our football players in full defensive armor would be to
a German. The Bursch wears a cap without
visor and a narrower neck band; if fighting in
a quarrel or with a Burschenschafter, he wears
no cap. Despite the costume, there is nothing
ludicrous in a fight between two good fencers.
The lightning-like flicker of the sword blades,
the rapidity of the wrist movements impress
the spectator. Fighting does not stop with first
blood drawn, but is continued for fifteen minutes of actual fencing, so that with pauses a
duel lasts over half an hour, unless the surgeon
pronounces it dangerous for one of the wounded combatants to continue.
Still, when one remembers that he sees the
last lineal survival of the gorgeous tournament of the middle ages, the steel-clad knights
fighting before their king and their ladies, sunk
to students fighting in a room in a squalid inn,
ready to run if the sentinel announces the corning of the university police, it seems an absurd anachronism at the end of the nineteenth

3

century. Another anachronism exists in the
attitude of the university authorities, who provide a fencing teacher and a fencing room
(Fechboden); both are actually used only by
those who intend fighting; yet the duel is
against the university law and the law of the
State, but is tacitly winked at by the authorities, who only let their police attempt a raid
once or twice in the term. As societies the
Corps and Burschenschafts are not only tolerated, but take a prominent part in all official
festivities.
I believe that dueling is beginning slowly to
die out. Thirty years ago nearly every student
of good family was a Corps student, and the
universities in smaller towns—Bonn, Heidelberg, Gottingen—were the favorite ones; they
still are with the sons of the Conservative nobility, but many of the better class of students
prefer the great city universities, do not join
the Corps or other societies, but find their
pleasure in general society and in the opera,
theatre, and indoor and outdoor concerts, which
are so cheap and good in Germany.
Are the dueling societies to be condemned?
T think not: they serve the purpose in Germany
which is better served by athletics with us; a
safety valve for high-spirited youths. As a
man in athletics learns to keep his temper, so
the Corps student learns to guard his tongue
and actions. The management or captaincy
of an athletic team may go far toward developing a man's character. An officer in a Corps
with its infinite detail of traditional etiquette,
the slightest departure from which is resented,
tends to prepare the student for the complex
social life of later years. My sketch of Corps
life is from memories of Jena many years ago,
but in the essentials it is correct today.
EDWARD RENOUF.

Commencement exercises will be held on the
afternoon of Tuesday. June 13, in the Academy
of Music, and will be followed by the usual reception to the graduates and their friends in
the evening at McCoy Hall. The number of
those who will receive diplomas is not far from
120, including 43 bachelors of arts, 39 doctors
of philosophy, and 33 doctors of medicine.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S next issue, the last of
the term, will mark the outgoing of the
Class of '99 by appearing in an enlarged and
illustrated form. This issue will be in circulation during the week following the examinations, and will be on sale at the commencement
exercises for a " merely nominal sum" of five
cents.
J$

The college world has now had time to inspect the '99 Hullabaloo, and the verdict is, on
the whole, highly favorable. The size of the
book has been somewhat reduced, and there are
few long articles, both of which innovations,
especially the last, are great improvements.
There are, perhaps, fewer "grinds" on the
men than formerly, and the grouping of students into departments is not uniformly correct, but the book is gotten up in more novel
and tasteful way than most others have been,
and the illustrations are unusually good.
.0

.0

Since our last issue, Hopkins has won a
championship and lost one. The lacrosse team
has proved beyond a doubt its superiority to
any college organization in the country, and
stands as a monument to the triumph of enthusiasm and conscientious work over obstacles
which threatened failure at the beginning.
It is to be regretted that the regular team could
not line up against the Crescents last Saturday,
for, since the new men have passed through
the ordeal of several games, the team would

probably have given the Brooklyn players
even a closer struggle than before. Success in
the championship contest has been expected
by the University ever since the present spirit
of determination manifested itself, and
credit for the victory must be assigned to
everyone. Maddren and Fitzgerald deserve
the lion's share of praise, but no one can overlook the faithful and steady co-operation of the
other veterans from last year's team, or the enthusiastic work of the seven new men, most of
whom acquired almost their whole knowledge
of lacrosse during the past year. Then, as
Maddren points out in another column, the
scrubs should not be forgotten—those self-sac.rificing patriots who take their share of hard
knocks without their share of glory. All deserve honor alike, and we are glad to see that
the undergraduate body seems disposed to show
appreciation of the efforts which have given us
a second championship.
But while rejoicing in victories on the lacrosse field, we should not withhold from the
baseball team its share of praise. We did not
come out first, it is true, but there is no organization in the University which has worked
under equally discouraging circumstances. At
the beginning of the year the Athletic Association considered the withdrawal of the team, and
when it was finally decided to maintain a nine,
material and, above all, support was lacking.
It is not fair to judge a team by the records of
its predecessors, and to refuse it support
because they have, in many instances, been unworthy. Our present team by no means merits
unqualified praise. It has not practiced as much
as it might have done, for its opportunities to
practice are no worse than those of other
teams and there are additional points which
might be criticised. The fact remains, however, that we have now the best baseball team
which has represented us for years, and this,
too, in spite of the non-appearance, from various causes, of several men upon whom it had
depended. The team seems to be on the road
to success, and if a few more good men develop, another year will amply vindicate the
wisdom of the policy which continues to support the national game at Hopkins.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
MEMBERS OF FACULTY ABROAD.

Several of the professors of the University
will spend the summer abroad, but nearly all of
them are engaged during their absence in carrying out their special studies.
Professors Newcomb and Ames are to represent the University at the jubilee of Sir
George Gabriel Stokes, the illustrious mathematician and physicist, who has been for fifty
years Lucasion professor of mathematics in the
University of Cambridge. The occasion will
be celebrated in Cambridge on the first and second of June, and will bring together the prominent physicists of the world. Professors Newcomb and Ames will also attend the one hundredth anniversary of the Royal Institution in
London, which was founded by the American,
Count Rumford, and has been under the direction, in later years, of Faraday, Tyndall and
Rayleigh. Professor Bloomfield is to he in
Germany supervising the publication of a facsimile of a remarkable Indian manuscript belonging to the University of Tubingen. Professor Haupt is actively engaged in the preparation of successive volumes of the Hebrew
Scriptures and the English translation. For
this purpose, he will visit the leading seats of
Oriental learning, and will represent the University at the twelfth International Congress
of Orientalists to be held in Rome in the early
autumn.
Professor Wood's departure was hastened
by the illness of his wife. He has been commissioned to make certain purchases of German
books for the library, the gift of a German
friend in Baltimore, and it is his expectation to
call upon Dr. Paulsen, the professor in Halle,
whose visit to Baltimore next year has already
been announced.

THE MASS-MEETING,

An enthusiastic meeting of students was held
last Thursday in Hopkins Hall to witness the
presentation of the H.'s and of prizes for gymnastic work. Ge-lice, Ge-ha's and congratulations flew thick and fast; and the effect of the
meeting was to give a general idea that Hopkins is going to wipe up the earth with every-

5

body next year. Maddren introduced Dr. Gilman, who presented the prizes won in the interclass gymnastic games, and spoke a few complimentary words to the recipients. He also
presented to the freshmen the silver cup awarded to the class scoring the largest number of
points in the gymnasium exhibition. The university H. was then presented by Mr. Maddren,
president of the Athletic Association to the following men: W. W. Simmons, for all-around
gymnastic work; Clark and Riggs, as members
of the relay team which recently won at the
University of Pennsylvania; George B. Scholl,
who tied for first place in the games at Georgetown, and to the new members of the champion lacrosse team—Foster, Grimes, Bruton,
Tyler, Sayler, Bandel and L. E. Griffin. Dr.
Renouf, Dr. Crenshaw and Captain Fitzgerald
also spoke briefly.
The individual prizes for gymnasium work
were awarded as follows: Werber, '99 ; Abercrombie, Baetjer and Morrison, all of igloo, received jerseys in the order named; R. E.
Humphreys received a pair of exhibition clubs,
as the prize for club-swinging. The medal
given by Mr. McLane to the best all-around
athlete was awarded to W. W. Simmons, and
medals for wrestling were presented to L. E.
Griffin, heavy-weight; H. C. Miller, middleweight, and L. G. Fishach, light-weight. The
members of the freshman tug-of-war team also
received medals, which were given by Mr.
James Hewes.
..11
The Physics room was darkened, and
Minor Physics breathed an atmosphere
charged with natural phenomena and lens
equations. W—d—r fairly oozed natural phenomena at every pore. He faced the intensely
interested class, and held between it and a
bunsen burner a gold leaf. He said:
"This ought to have a greenish tint. Gentlemen, do you see anything green?" As he
spoke, the light illuminated his massive features, and caused them to stand out in bold relief from the surrounding gloom. Seeing the
effect, the class drowsily answered:
-We think we do."

TO THE LACROSSE SCRUBS.
Now that the lacrosse season is ended—and
what a successful ending it was we all know—
I wish as coach of the team to thank the men
of the scrubs, to whose willing and most enthusiastic help during the entire season no small
measure of the success belongs. The work
done by these men who comprise the second
team is greatly underestimated, particularly
at Johns Hopkins, and therefore I want to take
this opportunity to show that their services are
appreciated.
They win no "H.," they cannot sport the
title of "champions," they enjoy none of the
fun of the trips away; and yet without them,
this year or any other year, our team could not
have become proficient. It is to these men who
have persevered without any material reward
that I am addressing this poor recognition of
their work.
I sincerely trust that these same men will
continue their good work next season, and if
the same spirit of willingness and enthusiasm
continues I hope to see—yes, and confidently
expect to see—many of them receive the highest honors the Athletic Association and the student body may bestow on the Inter-collegiate
Lacrosse Champions of I900.
WILLIAM HARVEY MADDREN.
What little things do often mar our brightest
expectations!
In our last issue we announced that we contemplated a baseball championship banner for
our common room this year. It would look
very pretty hung up on the wall with our lacrosse and relay banners, but, on second
thought, we concluded that we would not be
hasty about it. There is plenty of time, and
" all things come to him who waits." So we
have decided to wait a little.
The greatest influence that has prompted
us to this resolution was a party of young men
who came over here from the Maryland Agricultural College one Saturday morning to visit

our baseball team; and after two hours or so
spent in their company, Captain Joyner and his
gallant band decided to waive their claim to the
banner out of courtesy to the visitors.
We feel, naturally, somewhat disappointed,
for our hopes had risen high owing to the excellent record of the team so far. The men
worked together well and played a good, hard
game all through the season. They had their
ups and downs, as all teams have, and it happened that these were costly. Numerous obstacles in the early part of the season gave them
several set-backs. Clay Miller, who gave so
much promise at short-stop, was put out of the
game by a fencing accident. Radcliffe deserted
us, and Frazer, our expected twirler, never materialized. Strouse was thus left to do every
bit of the pitching, and it is somewhat of a
wonder that he did not break down. The
greatest thing that the team had to fight
against, however, was the open opposition that
was expressed by many prominent members of
the student body.
In spite of these drawbacks, the baseball
team has done excellent work. The game with
Princeton astonished every one, and the fact
that the Tigers were for six innings held down
to two runs is a source of much pride to us all.
In the game with the Baltimore team, critics
said that we made a showing equal to that of
Maryland University, whose team is exceptionally good this season. Our game with Washington College was a surprise to the whole
Inter-collegiate Association of the State, for
the collegians are generally considered invincible. The St. John's men, after their defeat,
conceded us the pennant, and Gallattdet showed
marked inferiority to us.
The fact remains, however, that the latter
beat us, and so did the M. A. C. The cause is
primarily due to lack of practice, and this.
again, is due to lack of grounds. If we did so
well this year without grounds, we may expect
the championship when we get a place to practice. In forming an estimate of the team's
work, there are more things to be considered
than appear at first sight, and we should remember successes rather than failures.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
INTERCOLLEGIATE CHArIPIONS.

And verily it came to pass that for the third
time there was joy in the heart of every loyal
Hopkins' son, for is not our lacrosse team
again the most high muck-a-muck among the
proud and mighty? And do not our ancient,
haughty rivals of Stevens, and of Lehigh, too,
now look up to the Black and Blue? All hail
to our great lacrosse team, the Intercollegiate
Champipns of 1899!
It occurred nearly two weeks ago, on the
home grounds of Lehigh.
Although the
score seems to indicate a one-sided, uninteresting game, nevertheless the game was interesting and replete with brilliant plays. Strange
to say, for once, our team was not lighter than
their opponents, but excelled even in this
minor detail.
The ball was faced off a little after 3.30 P. M.
As usual, for the first few minutes both sides
seemed to be suffering from nervousness, for
there was quite a little fumbling. The Lehigh
attack finally secured the ball, and in the next
minute made two good shots, which were cleverly stopped by Guggenheimer. Now "Aber"
gets the ball, and after a quick run, some brilliant passes and catches, and a swift shot, the
first goal is credited to Hopkins. Then another goal is made. Finally Digby, one of
Lehigh's crack players, sets the crowd wild by
sending the ball through our goal. During
the remainder of the half, McInnes, our great
and only "Canuck," gave an exhibition of how
to score five goals, even though the Lehigh
coach did nearly crack his throat by yelling,
"Cover McInnes, cover McInnes!" They did
cover him, but that only made it more interesting for "Mac."
The latter part of the second half was quite
a fizzle, for the rain simply poured down, and
this, coupled with the resulting miniature
lakes, commonly known as a lacrosse field,
made the play rather slow. The final score,
as we all know, was I I to 3.
The game, although slow at times, was exceedingly brilliant as a whole, and barring one
unfortunate melee, was exceptionally clean.
The chief trouble with Lehigh was that
their style of play, although well executed, was

7

badly conceived. The attack played too far
off to the side, while their defense did not
bunch enough around goal, and when they
did, were easily drawn out, thus giving our attack too many clean shots at goal.
It was just in these points thanks to Coach
Mathlren, that our team excelled, and this
fact, coupled with the fine individual playing
of the whole team, explains our victorious career this year, culminating in a third championship for dear old "Tom Hopkins."

A disorganized remnant of what is familiarly known as the Intercollegiate Champions
suffered an honorable defeat last Saturday at
the hands of the Crescent Athletic Club, the
champions of the world.
This game had been cancelled by the faculty, but at the earnest request of the Crescent
manager, who stated that he had already issued three thousand invitations to the game,
and as a personal favor to the Crescent team,
which came down here in order to give our
team good practice before the championship
series, the faculty veto was withdrawn. A
number of our crack players were unable to
go; as, for instance, Maddren, Griffin, Grimes
and Foster. Not only were these men missed,
but their absence caused half of the remainder
of the team to be played out of their position.
The game was far too one-sided to be exciting; but was interesting only on account of
the beautiful team work of the Crescents, for
the great work of McInnes at coverpoint, and
the truly fine work of "Guggy" in goal. This
was McInnes' first attempt at that position,

8

and to say he filled it, is putting it mildly.
"Jack" Curry, our former coach, who played
on the Crescent team, said that Guggenheimer's work was the finest exhibition of goalplaying he had ever seen. The remainder of
the team, with the exception of Abercrombie
and Fitzgerald, who although closely covered, played well, seemed to be suffering from
a well-developed case of the rattles. This
game was the last of this, our most successful, season.

°ERMAN UNIVERSITY LIFE.
I have been ,asked to write of certain phases
of student life in Germany. To understand
the German student one must know his previous school training. In the German grammar schools a boy who does not do his work
or is unruly is thrashed. in the high school—
called the Gymnasium—he is not thrashed, but
lighter offenses or poor work are punished by
house-arrest; i. e., his parents are informed
that for a given period he must remain in his
room outside of school hours, and do extra
tasks; continued insufficient scholarship entails
repeating the, work of the year, thus bringing
him to the university a year later than his
classmates; for graver offenses or incapacity
he is expelled.
This system has the approval of parents and
of the nation; its rigid discipline is in glaring
contrast with the democratic spirit of the American training school and college. Suffice it to
say that it suits Germany, and that it has certain obvious advantages. For nine years, and
those the years in which memory is most plastic, the boy, who has had good previous training in the grammar school, is compelled in the
Gymnasium to study hard, and learn thoroughly. The average result is a broad, thorough, and above all a lasting knowledge of his
own language and literature, of his country
and its resources, of classical and German history, of the classics and mathematics, and some
knowledge of modern languages, science, and
general history.
When the young man leaves the Gymnasium,
his education has reached a point which may
be roughly compared to the end of the junior
year in our colleges. Hence it follows that
German students are older than our college
students, the average age of entering the university being 19-20; that they all have a definite aim—medicine, law, etc.; that the univer-

No. 16

sity is a place for professional studies only;
and hence that'young men intending a business
life do not go to the University.
Yet one must not think that the German
student enters the university with the feelings
of an American graduate student, though his
aims are identical, and his educational status
nearly so. Without transition he comes from
the severe discipline of the school to absolute
freedom in the university; he may attend lectures or stay away for months at a time; he
may rarely enter the university buildings and
yet remain a student. Barring habits of work,
sense of duty, and comradeship, he has but two
incentives to work: First, how many years his
parents are willing to support him at the university; second, that he cannot practice law,
medicine or any other branch of learning in
Germany without passing certain examinations. Government sets a minimum university
residence before examination, varying from
three to five years, according to the subject of
study; the student may prolong this period indefinitely. Students who are poor, or exceptionally studious, usually pass the examinations
after the allotted minimum residence, and as a
rule take only a modest part in the characteristic pleasures of student life; most others stay
from six months to a year—often two years—
longer in residence, with consent of their parents, who wish them to enjoy a year or two
of comparative freedom from professional
study, that they may in part broaden their
knowledge in outside studies, in part share in
student life.
It must not be thought that this period is
commonly spent in loafing. A young man who
has graduated from the best schools in the
world has learned one thing at all events: he
has learned how to.work ; he can apply himself
closely to his studies,while indulging with equal
ardor in fencing matches or drinking bouts

later in the day. Indeed, that blot on democracy, the lack-lustre type of loafer which
reaches its highest perfection on the porch of
our village stores, vacuous in mind, empty of
purpose, and which in a more refined form occasionally gains entrance to our colleges, loafing through school, loafing through college, is
unknown in German universities; indeed, it is
almost unknown in Germany, thanks to their
system of enforced military service.
The German student, then, usually craves
occupation. What has he in place of our college life ? There is no class spirit" ; no one
thinks of himself as member of "the class of
'99"; it's a go-as-you-please race for graduation. There is scarce any "college spirit"; no
one asks, "Were you a Munich man?" They
ask, "Whom did you study under?" Many
students divide their time between two or three
universities, thus working with different distinguished teachers. Athletics as we understand the term are unknown, nor have they a
substitute in form of any game. Indoor athletics were compulsory at school. Some keep
on in the Turnschule provided by the university; unfortunately, there is a certain association ip the German mind of indoor gymnastics
with ultra-liberal political opinions, dating from
the days of "Turnvater Jahn," and the participation of student Turners in revolutionary
movements, which tends to keep many students
from the Turnschule.
Cycling, swimming,
boating, and mountaineering receive ever increasing interest. The Academische Gesangverein, with its high musical standards, attracts
the musically inclined, many in number. The
concerts of these societies are very enjoyable.
The picturesque side of student life is with
the Corps, the Burschenschaften, and their imitators. These bodies correspond to the American secret societies. The Corps are the lineal
descendant of the Landsmannschaften of the
middle ages, when all Saxons, for example, at
a given university, formed a corporation for
mutual help, often fighting in the streets, sword
in hand, against students from another province. In the general overturn of German
States and institutions under the Napoleonic
domination, the Landsmannschaften dropped

out of existence, but their names were retained
by their successors, the Corps. Now, corps
take members without reference to their home.
Some Corps are exclusive and expensive, some
the reverse. All have the following points in
common: Each Corps consists of Burschen, or
full members, and of Foxes, or probationers;
a Fox is usually made Bursch in eight months
or a year. Each Corps has three officers, or
"charges," which we may call president, vicepresident, treasurer; the vice-president has
charge of the dwelling. Each Corps is independent of all others, subject to general laws
laid down by the "Kosen Senioren-Convent,"
an annual assembly of delegates from all German Corps. Identity of name of Corps in different universities in no way implies affiliation.
Students of each Corps wear distinctive caps
and ribbon across the breast, of three colors
for the Bursch, of two for the Fox. All Corps
students"give satisfaction," to use the student
phrase, i. e., fight duels with the Schlager, a
heavy-hilted, light-bladed sword, on the most
trivial grounds, and lacking such, by simple arrangement of the vice-presidents. The Corps
have regular convivial meetings twice or thrice
weekly, when songs are sung and much—far
too much—beer is drunk. The Corps students
is not a Whitmanesque creature of impulse;
he is bound in things great and small by a
minute traditional etiquette. There are codified laws for dwelling, Pauk-comment; for beer
drinking, Bier-comment. Suppose a student to
pour wine or beer into his glass without murmuring "ohne" (abbreviation of ohne Bier
vergenden u wollen), he has committed a
grave offense. The learned in the law hold
that ohne should be said even if water be
poured, since it is clearly possible that the
pitcher might previously have contained beer,
and thus a drop might so temper and ennoble
the water as to bring it within spiritual relationship to beer, though to the outward eye it be
plain water. The offending student is condemned by the president to a penalty—song or
drink. He may appeal and demand trial; an
impromptu court is held with counsel, and
clever speeches, sometimes in Latin wonderfully burlesqued. The student who demands

THE NEWS-LETTER.
trial must order three glasses of schnaps for
judge and counsel. Tradition demands that
they refuse it as hurtful to the stomach, and
that it be drunk by the waiter! During term
time it is etiquette for the student to ignore
the existence of a member of a rival Corps,
though they may be old friends; with the
moment of close of term, they are again friends.
Hazing is unknown. There is no initiation
analogous to that of American secret societies.
The chief difference between Corps and
BursChenschaft is that the latter avow advanced
democratic political opinions. The Burschenschafts "give satisfaction," and fight among
each other, but chiefly with the Corps. Other
societies wear colored cap and ribbon, but "re:
fuse satisfaction" ; the students belonging to
them are generally a shabby lot; some of these
latter societies are semi-religious, Catholic or
Protestant.
A Fox equipped for a fight is a strange
object; with his body protected by a padded
leather apron, his neck by a broad, wadded silk
band, half covering the chin, his eyes by a sort
of stone-masons' goggles without glasses, his
temples by a light cap with broad visor; he is
to American eyes as comical as one of our football players in full defensive armor would be to
a German. The Bursch wears a cap without
visor and a narrower neck band; if fighting in
a quarrel or with a Burschenschafter, he wears
no cap. Despite the costume, there is nothing
ludicrous in a fight between two good fencers.
The lightning-like flicker of the sword blades,
the rapidity of the wrist movements impress
the spectator. Fighting does not stop with first
blood drawn, but is continued for fifteen minutes of actual fencing, so that with pauses a
duel lasts over half an hour, unless the surgeon
pronounces it dangerous for one of the wounded combatants to continue.
Still, when one remembers that he sees the
last lineal survival of the gorgeous tournament of the middle ages, the steel-clad knights
fighting before their king and their ladies, sunk
to students fighting in a room in a squalid inn,
ready to run if the sentinel announces the corning of the university police, it seems an absurd anachronism at the end of the nineteenth

3

century. Another anachronism exists in the
attitude of the university authorities, who provide a fencing teacher and a fencing room
(Fechboden); both are actually used only by
those who intend fighting; yet the duel is
against the university law and the law of the
State, but is tacitly winked at by the authorities, who only let their police attempt a raid
once or twice in the term. As societies the
Corps and Burschenschafts are not only tolerated, but take a prominent part in all official
festivities.
I believe that dueling is beginning slowly to
die out. Thirty years ago nearly every student
of good family was a Corps student, and the
universities in smaller towns—Bonn, Heidelberg, Gottingen—were the favorite ones; they
still are with the sons of the Conservative nobility, but many of the better class of students
prefer the great city universities, do not join
the Corps or other societies, but find their
pleasure in general society and in the opera,
theatre, and indoor and outdoor concerts, which
are so cheap and good in Germany.
Are the dueling societies to be condemned?
T think not: they serve the purpose in Germany
which is better served by athletics with us; a
safety valve for high-spirited youths. As a
man in athletics learns to keep his temper, so
the Corps student learns to guard his tongue
and actions. The management or captaincy
of an athletic team may go far toward developing a man's character. An officer in a Corps
with its infinite detail of traditional etiquette,
the slightest departure from which is resented,
tends to prepare the student for the complex
social life of later years. My sketch of Corps
life is from memories of Jena many years ago,
but in the essentials it is correct today.
EDWARD RENOUF.

The college world has now had time to inspect the '99 Hullabaloo, and the verdict is, on
the whole, highly favorable. The size of the
book has been somewhat reduced, and there are
few long articles, both of which innovations,
especially the last, are great improvements.
There are, perhaps, fewer "grinds" on the
men than formerly, and the grouping of students into departments is not uniformly correct, but the book is gotten up in more novel
and tasteful way than most others have been,
and the illustrations are unusually good.

Since our last issue, Hopkins has won a
championship and lost one. The lacrosse team
has proved beyond a doubt its superiority to
any college organization in the country, and
stands as a monument to the triumph of enthusiasm and conscientious work over obstacles
which threatened failure at the beginning.
It is to be regretted that the regular team could
not line up against the Crescents last Saturday,
for, since the new men have passed through
the ordeal of several games, the team would

probably have given the Brooklyn players
even a closer struggle than before. Success in
the championship contest has been expected
by the University ever since the present spirit
of determination manifested itself, and
credit for the victory must be assigned to
everyone. Maddren and Fitzgerald deserve
the lion's share of praise, but no one can overlook the faithful and steady co-operation of the
other veterans from last year's team, or the enthusiastic work of the seven new men, most of
whom acquired almost their whole knowledge
of lacrosse during the past year. Then, as
Maddren points out in another column, the
scrubs should not be forgotten—those self-sac.rificing patriots who take their share of hard
knocks without their share of glory. All deserve honor alike, and we are glad to see that
the undergraduate body seems disposed to show
appreciation of the efforts which have given us
a second championship.
But while rejoicing in victories on the lacrosse field, we should not withhold from the
baseball team its share of praise. We did not
come out first, it is true, but there is no organization in the University which has worked
under equally discouraging circumstances. At
the beginning of the year the Athletic Association considered the withdrawal of the team, and
when it was finally decided to maintain a nine,
material and, above all, support was lacking.
It is not fair to judge a team by the records of
its predecessors, and to refuse it support
because they have, in many instances, been unworthy. Our present team by no means merits
unqualified praise. It has not practiced as much
as it might have done, for its opportunities to
practice are no worse than those of other
teams and there are additional points which
might be criticised. The fact remains, however, that we have now the best baseball team
which has represented us for years, and this,
too, in spite of the non-appearance, from various causes, of several men upon whom it had
depended. The team seems to be on the road
to success, and if a few more good men develop, another year will amply vindicate the
wisdom of the policy which continues to support the national game at Hopkins.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
MEMBERS OF FACULTY ABROAD.

Several of the professors of the University
will spend the summer abroad, but nearly all of
them are engaged during their absence in carrying out their special studies.
Professors Newcomb and Ames are to represent the University at the jubilee of Sir
George Gabriel Stokes, the illustrious mathematician and physicist, who has been for fifty
years Lucasion professor of mathematics in the
University of Cambridge. The occasion will
be celebrated in Cambridge on the first and second of June, and will bring together the prominent physicists of the world. Professors Newcomb and Ames will also attend the one hundredth anniversary of the Royal Institution in
London, which was founded by the American,
Count Rumford, and has been under the direction, in later years, of Faraday, Tyndall and
Rayleigh. Professor Bloomfield is to he in
Germany supervising the publication of a facsimile of a remarkable Indian manuscript belonging to the University of Tubingen. Professor Haupt is actively engaged in the preparation of successive volumes of the Hebrew
Scriptures and the English translation. For
this purpose, he will visit the leading seats of
Oriental learning, and will represent the University at the twelfth International Congress
of Orientalists to be held in Rome in the early
autumn.
Professor Wood's departure was hastened
by the illness of his wife. He has been commissioned to make certain purchases of German
books for the library, the gift of a German
friend in Baltimore, and it is his expectation to
call upon Dr. Paulsen, the professor in Halle,
whose visit to Baltimore next year has already
been announced.

last Thursday in Hopkins Hall to witness the
presentation of the H.'s and of prizes for gymnastic work. Ge-lice, Ge-ha's and congratulations flew thick and fast; and the effect of the
meeting was to give a general idea that Hopkins is going to wipe up the earth with every-

The Physics room was darkened, and
Minor Physics breathed an atmosphere
charged with natural phenomena and lens
equations. W—d—r fairly oozed natural phenomena at every pore. He faced the intensely
interested class, and held between it and a
bunsen burner a gold leaf. He said:
"This ought to have a greenish tint. Gentlemen, do you see anything green?" As he
spoke, the light illuminated his massive features, and caused them to stand out in bold relief from the surrounding gloom. Seeing the
effect, the class drowsily answered:
-We think we do."

TO THE LACROSSE SCRUBS.
Now that the lacrosse season is ended—and
what a successful ending it was we all know—
I wish as coach of the team to thank the men
of the scrubs, to whose willing and most enthusiastic help during the entire season no small
measure of the success belongs. The work
done by these men who comprise the second
team is greatly underestimated, particularly
at Johns Hopkins, and therefore I want to take
this opportunity to show that their services are
appreciated.
They win no "H.," they cannot sport the
title of "champions," they enjoy none of the
fun of the trips away; and yet without them,
this year or any other year, our team could not
have become proficient. It is to these men who
have persevered without any material reward
that I am addressing this poor recognition of
their work.
I sincerely trust that these same men will
continue their good work next season, and if
the same spirit of willingness and enthusiasm
continues I hope to see—yes, and confidently
expect to see—many of them receive the highest honors the Athletic Association and the student body may bestow on the Inter-collegiate
Lacrosse Champions of I900.
WILLIAM HARVEY MADDREN.
What little things do often mar our brightest
expectations!
In our last issue we announced that we contemplated a baseball championship banner for
our common room this year. It would look
very pretty hung up on the wall with our lacrosse and relay banners, but, on second
thought, we concluded that we would not be
hasty about it. There is plenty of time, and
" all things come to him who waits." So we
have decided to wait a little.
The greatest influence that has prompted
us to this resolution was a party of young men
who came over here from the Maryland Agricultural College one Saturday morning to visit

our baseball team; and after two hours or so
spent in their company, Captain Joyner and his
gallant band decided to waive their claim to the
banner out of courtesy to the visitors.
We feel, naturally, somewhat disappointed,
for our hopes had risen high owing to the excellent record of the team so far. The men
worked together well and played a good, hard
game all through the season. They had their
ups and downs, as all teams have, and it happened that these were costly. Numerous obstacles in the early part of the season gave them
several set-backs. Clay Miller, who gave so
much promise at short-stop, was put out of the
game by a fencing accident. Radcliffe deserted
us, and Frazer, our expected twirler, never materialized. Strouse was thus left to do every
bit of the pitching, and it is somewhat of a
wonder that he did not break down. The
greatest thing that the team had to fight
against, however, was the open opposition that
was expressed by many prominent members of
the student body.
In spite of these drawbacks, the baseball
team has done excellent work. The game with
Princeton astonished every one, and the fact
that the Tigers were for six innings held down
to two runs is a source of much pride to us all.
In the game with the Baltimore team, critics
said that we made a showing equal to that of
Maryland University, whose team is exceptionally good this season. Our game with Washington College was a surprise to the whole
Inter-collegiate Association of the State, for
the collegians are generally considered invincible. The St. John's men, after their defeat,
conceded us the pennant, and Gallattdet showed
marked inferiority to us.
The fact remains, however, that the latter
beat us, and so did the M. A. C. The cause is
primarily due to lack of practice, and this.
again, is due to lack of grounds. If we did so
well this year without grounds, we may expect
the championship when we get a place to practice. In forming an estimate of the team's
work, there are more things to be considered
than appear at first sight, and we should remember successes rather than failures.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
INTERCOLLEGIATE CHArIPIONS.

And verily it came to pass that for the third
time there was joy in the heart of every loyal
Hopkins' son, for is not our lacrosse team
again the most high muck-a-muck among the
proud and mighty? And do not our ancient,
haughty rivals of Stevens, and of Lehigh, too,
now look up to the Black and Blue? All hail
to our great lacrosse team, the Intercollegiate
Champipns of 1899!
It occurred nearly two weeks ago, on the
home grounds of Lehigh.
Although the
score seems to indicate a one-sided, uninteresting game, nevertheless the game was interesting and replete with brilliant plays. Strange
to say, for once, our team was not lighter than
their opponents, but excelled even in this
minor detail.
The ball was faced off a little after 3.30 P. M.
As usual, for the first few minutes both sides
seemed to be suffering from nervousness, for
there was quite a little fumbling. The Lehigh
attack finally secured the ball, and in the next
minute made two good shots, which were cleverly stopped by Guggenheimer. Now "Aber"
gets the ball, and after a quick run, some brilliant passes and catches, and a swift shot, the
first goal is credited to Hopkins. Then another goal is made. Finally Digby, one of
Lehigh's crack players, sets the crowd wild by
sending the ball through our goal. During
the remainder of the half, McInnes, our great
and only "Canuck," gave an exhibition of how
to score five goals, even though the Lehigh
coach did nearly crack his throat by yelling,
"Cover McInnes, cover McInnes!" They did
cover him, but that only made it more interesting for "Mac."
The latter part of the second half was quite
a fizzle, for the rain simply poured down, and
this, coupled with the resulting miniature
lakes, commonly known as a lacrosse field,
made the play rather slow. The final score,
as we all know, was I I to 3.
The game, although slow at times, was exceedingly brilliant as a whole, and barring one
unfortunate melee, was exceptionally clean.
The chief trouble with Lehigh was that
their style of play, although well executed, was

7

badly conceived. The attack played too far
off to the side, while their defense did not
bunch enough around goal, and when they
did, were easily drawn out, thus giving our attack too many clean shots at goal.
It was just in these points thanks to Coach
Mathlren, that our team excelled, and this
fact, coupled with the fine individual playing
of the whole team, explains our victorious career this year, culminating in a third championship for dear old "Tom Hopkins."

A disorganized remnant of what is familiarly known as the Intercollegiate Champions
suffered an honorable defeat last Saturday at
the hands of the Crescent Athletic Club, the
champions of the world.
This game had been cancelled by the faculty, but at the earnest request of the Crescent
manager, who stated that he had already issued three thousand invitations to the game,
and as a personal favor to the Crescent team,
which came down here in order to give our
team good practice before the championship
series, the faculty veto was withdrawn. A
number of our crack players were unable to
go; as, for instance, Maddren, Griffin, Grimes
and Foster. Not only were these men missed,
but their absence caused half of the remainder
of the team to be played out of their position.
The game was far too one-sided to be exciting; but was interesting only on account of
the beautiful team work of the Crescents, for
the great work of McInnes at coverpoint, and
the truly fine work of "Guggy" in goal. This
was McInnes' first attempt at that position,
